items.author: Shawn Levy
items.content: The Matrix slams you back in your chair, pops open your eyes and leaves your jaw hanging slack in amazement.

items.author: Keith Phipps
items.content: The Wachowskis do it so playfully well, keeping The Matrix's potentially confusing plot intelligible, intelligent, and suspenseful, that it doesn't matter.

items.author: Manohla Dargis
items.content: Bill Pope's swooping, noir-inflected cinematography is wonderfully complemented by Owen Paterson's inventive production design, a great soundtrack and the best fight choreography this side of Hong Kong. And even if this isn't "Blade Runner," it is very cool shit.

items.author: James Berardinelli
items.content: Kinetic, atmospheric, visually stunning, and mind-bending.

items.author: Stephen Hunter
items.content: There's a kind of liberating, almost transforming energy in this film; it lights you up and sends you out all giddy with silliness.

items.author: Marc Savlov
items.content: Doesn't just raise the bar on sci-fi and action films, it rips that sucker off and sends it spiraling into the sun.

items.author: David Sterritt
items.content: The plot switches gears every time it threatens to run out of energy, which keeps the show as lively as it is preposterous.

items.author: Sean Means
items.content: Aerves up so much visual wizardry and thought-provoking ideas that even the inevitable Silver touch -- a finale with more bullets than the opening of "Saving Private Ryan" -- can't destroy the magic.

items.author: Andrew O'Hehir
items.content: It may bore you to death or blow your mind -- and it's long and convoluted enough to do both -- but it holds nothing back.

items.author: Jonathan Rosenbaum
items.content: There's not much humor to keep it all life-size, and by the final stretch it's become bloated, mechanical, and tiresome.
